questions.question: The anorectal angle is formed by which muscle?
What is the length of the adult rectum?
questions.explanation: The adult rectum is approximately 12-18 cm in length and is conventionally divided into threeequal parts - the upper, middle and lower 1/3rd.

questions.question: Which fascial layer should be dissected to separate the rectum from the coccyx whileoperating on a patient with rectal adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx.The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:•from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers' fascia• from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer's fasciaWaldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses withthe rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into601superior and inferior compartments.Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventingcomplications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.Denonvillier's and Waldeyer's fasciaOMARROWRectal proper fascia(Visceral endopelvicfascia)Presacral fascia(Parietal endopelvicfascia)Waldeyer's fascia(Rectosacral fascia)Denonvillier's fascia(Rectogenital fascia)

questions.question: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of thefollowing conditions?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures.Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acuteanal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operatingroom.602Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:• Rectal bleeding.Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea• Pain or difficulty in defecation• Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids• Rectal prolapse.

questions.question: An anxious mother rushed her 2-year-old child to the casualty when she noticed ared-coloured mass protruding from his anus. The mother gave a history of the child strainingwhile passing stools for the past 2 weeks. There was no abdominal tenderness, and on localexamination, a 6 cm mass with circumferential folds and slight edema was noted. How willyou manage this child?
questions.explanation: The given history and examination finding is suggestive of rectal prolapse. In children, theprolapse is usually mucosal and should be treated conservatively.Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes throughthe anal orifice.Conservative treatment for rectal prolapse in children is to control:• Diarrhea• Worm infestation• MalnutritionSclerotherapy can also be used.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of patients withrectal prolapse?

options.A: Surgery is necessary for full-thickness rectal prolapse
options.B: Delorme's operation is done via the perineal approach
options.C: Ripstein's procedure is done via abdominal approach
options.D: Abdominal rectopexy is often preferred in high risk individuals

questions.explanation: The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited lifeexpectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrencerate.Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients,particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders.Perineal procedures:• Delorme's mucosectomy- involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapseusing interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anaesthesia.• Thiersch's encirclement- a steel wire, or Silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal.Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructeddefaecation• Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associatedsigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated bypoor bowel control with faecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir.Abdominal procedures:• Suture rectopexy603• Mesh rectopexy• Posterior (Well's and Ivalon's)•• Anterior (Ripstein's)• Lateral (Orr-Loygue)•• Ventral• Resection Rectopexy (Frykman-Goldberg)The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normalanatomical position.Delorme procedureMARectal prolapseDelorme procedureOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding solitary rectal ulcers?

options.A: Commonly seen on the posterior wall
options.B: Rectal bleeding Is a common presentation
options.D: Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice

questions.explanation: A solitary rectal ulcer is usually located on the anterior rectal wall, 6-8 cm from the anal verge.It commonly presents with rectal bleeding in the setting of chronic straining orconstipation. Histology reveals a thick layer of fibrosis obliterating the lamina propria and acentral fibrinous exudate.Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnostic evaluation, whiledefecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice.Stapled trans-anal rectal resection(STARR procedure) is the management of choice.

questions.question: What is the radiological procedure of choice in patients suspected to have a solitary rectalulcer?
questions.explanation: Defecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice for diagnostic evaluation insolitary rectal ulcer syndrome (SRUS). Some common findings include:• Full-thickness rectal prolapse604• Internal prolapse• Paradoxical puborectalis syndrome•• Thickened rectal foldsDefecography evaluates in real-time the morphology of the rectum and anal canal in a physiologicsetting by injection of a thick barium paste into the rectum and its subsequent evacuation.It is primarily performed for workup of patients with:•• Longstanding constipation• Unexplained anal or rectal pain• Residual sensation after defecation•Suspected prolapse.

questions.question: What is the earliest manifestation in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Per-rectal bleeding is the earliest and most common symptom of rectal carcinoma.Other symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:• Mucus drainage• Tenesmus•Early morning diarrhoea• Pain•Weight loss.

questions.question: An elderly man with per-rectal bleeding is suspected to have rectal carcinoma. Which of thefollowing is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Majority of the cancers are sporadic
options.B: Dose of radiation used for this tumor is 45 Gy
options.C: Dissection lateral to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence
options.D: Precise location of the tumor is determined with rigid proctosigmoidoscopy

questions.explanation: Dissection medial (not lateral) to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes localrecurrence.Dissection lateral to the avascular anatomic space, risks injury to the mixed autonomic nerves,causing impotence in men and bladder dysfunction in men and women.Transmesorectal resection involves complete removal of the lymph node bearing mesorectumalong with its intact enveloping fascia. It is a curative resection of rectal tumours of the middleand lower thirds of the rectum, either as part of Low Anterior Resection (LAR) orAbdominoperineal Resection (APR).606Option A: The majority of colorectal cancers are sporadic. Approximately 5% of all colorectalcancers are attributed to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome (hereditarynon-polyposis colorectal cancer).Option B: The large bowel can tolerate delivered radiation doses of up to 6000 cGy. However,a lower dose of 45 Gy is recommended for colorectal tumours. High levels of radiation targeted atcolon tumours would include the small bowel in the treatment field. This results in complicationssuch as radiation enteritis.Option D: The precise location of the rectal tumour is determined using rigidproctosigmoidoscope or flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy. The other investigations used in rectalcancer include:• Digital rectal examination - for assessing the depth of penetration•• Endorectal ultrasound or MRI - provides an accurate assessment of the extent of invasion of thebowel wall•MRI with an endorectal coil - is the investigation of choice to assess the 'T' and 'N' stages• CECT for evaluation of metastasis.-

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?

options.A: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
options.B: Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
options.C: Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
options.D: Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.explanation: Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.Colorectal cancer is:• The second most common malignancy globally•The second most common cancer in women••• The third most common cancer in menThe fourth most common cause of death due to cancer.Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:• Painless bleeding - earliest and most common• Alteration of bowel habits - change in frequency and consistency of the stool•• Tenesmus - unable to pass a motion even when there is the sensation of needing to evacuate thebowel. It is suggestive of a tumor of the lower half of the rectum•Early morning bloody diarrhea (option C) - passage of blood and mucus in addition to feces. Painand weight loss are usually late symptomsAbdominal examination and digital rectal examination are used for the primary evaluation. Rigidsigmoidoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy. A synchronous tumor (primary tumor with adifferent origin than the one currently investigated) is excluded by performing a colonoscopy.Modified Duke's classification:607ABCDGrowth limited up to the rectal mucosa (option D)B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph nodemetastasis.C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and 1ymph node metastasis.Distant metastasisModified Dukes' stagingStageAB₁BzExtentoftumordeeper thannosubmucosaMucosaMuscularismucosaSubmucosaMuscularispropriaSerosaFatLymphnodesC₁C₂Dnotthroughbowel wallthroughbowel wallnot throughbowel wall;lymph nodemetastasesthroughbowel wall;lymph nodemetastasesdistantmetast-atesnOMARROWLungLiverBoneSkinSurgery is the mainstay of management for rectal carcinoma. Non-operative management isoffered to only those patients who have a complete clinical response to neoadjuvant.The type of surgery depends on multiple factors (size, location, age of the patient, etc). However,the general consensus is:• Early cancer (T1 and a few T2) is locally excised via the transanal approach.• Most rectal cancer is treated by anterior resection and colorectal/coloanal anastomosis.• Low extensive tumors are treated by laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection(APR) andpermanent colostomy.• Hartmann's operation (option A) is preferred in old and frail patients due to poor anal sphincterand postoperative incontinence.

questions.question: In patients with rectal carcinoma, what is the investigation of choice for assessment ofperirectal nodes and the depth of penetration?
questions.explanation: 608Endorectal-coil magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best modality for predicting lymphnode invasion and overall local staging.It can identify involved perirectal nodes on the basis of characteristics other than size. It can alsoidentify foci at sites not only within the mesorectum but also outside the mesorectal fascia, suchas pelvic sidewalls, and can identify the depth of penetration.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site of blood-borne metastasis in patients withrectal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: The principal sites for blood-borne metastases in rectal carcinoma arethe liver > lungs > adrenals.

questions.question: A patient with rectal carcinoma is posted under your unit for surgery. Which of the followingcorrectly describes the margins of clearance that will be required in this surgery?
questions.explanation: The margins of clearance required for the surgery of rectal carcinoma is:• Proximal - 5 cm611•• Distal - 2 cm• Radial- 5 cm (for the removal of mesorectal nodes)Historically, a 5 cm clearance margin was the common practice. However, the 5 cm rule has beenreplaced by the 2 cm rule to help preserve the anal sphincters.When a negative distal margin can be achieved by sparing the sphincter, a sphincter sparingsurgery such as low anterior resection (LAR) is performed.If it is not possible to achieve a negative distal margin and spare the sphincter (when the tumouris within 5cm of anal verge), abdominal perineal resection (APR) is done.APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymphnode retrieval.

questions.question: 598A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools for thepast 3 months. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which islocated 8 cm from the anal verge. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. Which of thefollowing surgeries would you prefer in managing this patient?
questions.explanation: Low anterior resection (LAR) is the preferred surgery in rectal carcinoma which is located at least55.5 cm away from the anal verge.It is not performed:• If adequate margin could not be achieved even after preoperative chemoradiotherapy.• If the sphincters have to be sacrificed to achieve an adequate margin• In patients who cannot tolerate low anastomosis.In such cases, where anterior resection cannot be performed in distal rectal cancers,abdominoperineal resection (APR) is done.APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymphnode retrieval.

questions.question: Transanal local excision can be done in rectal carcinoma patients with all of the followingtumour features except

options.A: Tumor within 8 cm of the anal verge
options.D: T2 tumor without lymph node involvement

questions.explanation: T2 rectal cancers are managed by transabdominal resection.Transanal local excision is recommended for selected T1, No early-stage cancers which fulfill thefollowing criteria:• Small (<3 cm), well- to moderately-differentiated tumors•• Tumors within 8 cm of the anal verge• Tumors limited to <30% of the rectal circumference• Tumors with no evidence of nodal involvement• Full-thickness excision must be feasible.612

questions.question: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is used for treating patients with rectalcarcinoma?
questions.explanation: 5-Fluorouracil-based regimens with leucovorin and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) reduce recurrence andimprove survival in patients with colorectal carcinoma.Irinotecan (FOLFIRI regimen) is also used as a second-line chemotherapy agent. Adjuvantchemotherapy is routinely recommended in patients with lymph node involvement.Option B: ABVD regimen is used for Hodgkin's lymphoma.Option C: RCHOP regimen is used for B-cell Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma.

questions.question: An 80-year-old man with rectal carcinoma presented with features of intestinal obstruction.How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: Hartmann's operation is an excellent procedure in an elderly, frail patient in whom there isconcern about anal sphincter function or the viability of an anastomosis.Through an abdominal incision, the rectum is excised, the rectal stump is stapled closed and theproximal colon exteriorized as a permanent end colostomy.Note: Endoluminal stenting is being increasingly used in patients with obstructing carcinomas. Itcan be either used as a palliative procedure or to relieve the obstruction. Only rectosigmoid andupper rectal tumours are suitable for stenting because stent impingement on the anorectum inlow cancers can result in tenesmus.613
